For The Record
One of the most persistent misconceptions concerning what may loosely be termed the Hopkins Community
is that the Faculty of Philosophy and the School of Engineering Science bear no relation to each other, that the
two are isolated entities which happen to share the same
campus. The members of each group, at least on the
undergraduate level, tend to regard the other with indifference if not with disdain. Yet, in spite of the obviously
great disparity between the sort of education which
accompanies a B.A. and that which leads to a Bachelor
of Engineering Science, there are fundamental similari- ties in educational approach which are too often overlooked.
The barrage of publicity which heralds the fiftieth
anniversary of the School of Engineering Science serves
to point out an approach to education which is very
much like that of the Faculty of Philosophy, and perhaps
peculiar to Johns Hopkins. In short, the emphasis is on
a thorough grounding in an intellectual method rather
than on the teaching of pragmatic skills or the accumulation of useful data. Phenomena in and for themselves
are less important than the analysis of the abstract principles, the general rules, which underlie them.
This non-pragmatic approach is stressed over and
over in the publications of the Engineering School. It
explains the unusually intense courses in the theoretical
aspects of his field to which the Hopkins Engineer is
subjected. It is also undoubtedly a major factor in determining the high proportion of Engineers who take
advanced degrees; such an orientation is far more likely
to produce scholars and teachers than to prepare skilled
practitioners. All of this is to a large extent parallel to
the way the majority of courses are taught in the liberal
arts and "pure" sciences. Once more the emphasis is
less on factual data than on the causes, be they social,
political, or metaphysical which underlie specific literary
or historial manifestations. Again it is the abstract which
is stressed, and again the result is to train scholars and
teachers.
In ignoring this unifying concept in the educational
philosophies of the two major divisions of Hopkins most
people miss the fact that there does seem to be some
order, some general direction, in the apparently offhand
teaching of undergraduates here.

The Dance Band Won't
Sfop Here Any More
The policy of the athletic department and the plant
manager's office regarding the use of the gym floor has
apparently limited all future dances at Homewood to the
sock hop variety and has, in effect, forced organizations
wishing to utilize the gym for dances to sustain heavy
financial losses.
For an organization to obtain the gymnasium, it
must pay exorbitant fees to buy paper to cover the gym
floor in order to insure that it will not be damaged.
While an organization has always had to pay for janitorial services, as well as for tables, chairs and decorations
when preparing the gym for a dance, it will now have
to pay for floor covering as well.
The DSRC-sponsored Pajama Ball would have
made money had there been no fee for the gym floor.
While this fee, which amounts to approximately $125
has yet to be paid, it will account for the difference
between profit or loss on the dance. Since the PJ Ball
had a heavy turnout, its case can be assumed to be
typical.
To add to the plight of organizations wishing to
sponsor dances, Mr. Turner has recently stated that no
high heels may be worn at the next dance in his effort
to determine the amount of damage "spikes" cause. Mr.
Turner adds, however, that he is interested in experimenting with a set of rules and regulations which will
remain in flux for the next two years when the addition
to the gymnasium will be completed and a uniform
flooring available.
Mr. Turner's efforts to create human factors out of
would-be dancers will in the end result in no human
factors at all. For, if organizations cannot profit from
dances, they will cease to sponsor them. Mr. Turner's
effort to prevent would-be damage can gain little sympathy from the undergraduate viewpoint. If the gym is
really a recreation center, as he would like to call it,
it must function as such. In the long run the gym will
more than likely be used for dances as it has been in
the past. In Mr. Turner's effort to prevent jts disuse,
he is preventing any normal utilization of it.

For The Record
One of the most persistent misconceptions concerning what may loosely be termed the Hopkins Community
is that the Faculty of Philosophy and the School of Engineering Science bear no relation to each other, that the
two are isolated entities which happen to share the same
campus. The members of each group, at least on the
undergraduate level, tend to regard the other with indifference if not with disdain. Yet, in spite of the obviously
great disparity between the sort of education which
accompanies a B.A. and that which leads to a Bachelor
of Engineering Science, there are fundamental similari- ties in educational approach which are too often overlooked.
The barrage of publicity which heralds the fiftieth
anniversary of the School of Engineering Science serves
to point out an approach to education which is very
much like that of the Faculty of Philosophy, and perhaps
peculiar to Johns Hopkins. In short, the emphasis is on
a thorough grounding in an intellectual method rather
than on the teaching of pragmatic skills or the accumulation of useful data. Phenomena in and for themselves
are less important than the analysis of the abstract principles, the general rules, which underlie them.
This non-pragmatic approach is stressed over and
over in the publications of the Engineering School. It
explains the unusually intense courses in the theoretical
aspects of his field to which the Hopkins Engineer is
subjected. It is also undoubtedly a major factor in determining the high proportion of Engineers who take
advanced degrees; such an orientation is far more likely
to produce scholars and teachers than to prepare skilled
practitioners. All of this is to a large extent parallel to
the way the majority of courses are taught in the liberal
arts and "pure" sciences. Once more the emphasis is
less on factual data than on the causes, be they social,
political, or metaphysical which underlie specific literary
or historial manifestations. Again it is the abstract which
is stressed, and again the result is to train scholars and
teachers.
In ignoring this unifying concept in the educational
philosophies of the two major divisions of Hopkins most
people miss the fact that there does seem to be some
order, some general direction, in the apparently offhand
teaching of undergraduates here.
